I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  To provide relevant information and analysis, to contribute to the intellectual environment 
in which policy formulation occurs, and to maintain and enhance its reputation as a credible and 
authoritative  source  of  knowledge  about  the  region,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
regularly monitors and offers commentary on evolving developments in its developing member 
countries (DMCs). The Asian Development Outlook1 (ADO) is the principal vehicle for delivery 
of these services regionwide.  The content of ADO also informs Management opinion and 
guides institutional views about prospective developments and other important issues. ADO has 
been a flagship publication of ADB since 1989.  The preparation, publication, and dissemination 
of ADO has been regularly supported by technical assistance (TA) funding.  Appendix 1 sets out 
the objectives, scope, and activities to be covered by the regional TA.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Ongoing  efforts  to  improve  the  quality  of  ADO  are  focused  on  providing  stronger 
analytical content and ensuring better cohesion and balance among its parts. These initiatives 
respond to feedback from clients and to a changing environment and market for economic 
information  and  analysis.  Efforts  to  improve  the  quality  of  analysis  will  include  the 
commissioning of relevant applied and policy research at a country and regional level, the 
development of new sources of information, and strengthened peer review. In an increasingly 
competitive market for knowledge and information, high-quality editing services are critical to 
ensure that ADO’s key messages are communicated effectively.  The Economics and Research 
Department (ERD) will continue to work with ADB’s Department of External Relations (DER) to 
increase ADO’s regional and international reach. 
 
3.  The TA will support activities that will contribute to high-quality content and help ensure 
the usefulness and relevance of ADO to policy dialogue and formulation in DMCs. Currently, 
ADO is the most frequently downloaded publication from ADB’s website and is directly or 
indirectly the source of much international and national news commentary that features analysis, 
views, and opinions from ADB.  Elevating ADO’s profile further and widening its influence will 
require a concerted effort not just to improve quality but to differentiate and disseminate content. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
4.  The main outputs from the TA will be ADO 2007 and ADO 2007 Update. Activities 
supported under the TA will also feed into the preparation of subsequent years’ ADOs.  Draft 
contents pages of ADO 2007 and ADO 2007 Update are in Appendix 2. The major thematic 
focus in 2007 will be on the links between Asia’s structural transformation and new growth 
patterns. It is expected that related issues will feature in many country chapters and will be 
covered at a regional and subregional level in Parts 1 and 3.  
 
                                                 
1  The Asian Development Outlook (ADO) is sold externally, and is extensively reviewed and commented on in 
the media. It is also the most popular document on the ADB website. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 26 July 2006.

2   
5.  The TA will further develop and refine analytical methods to support ADB’s short- and 
medium-term country economic monitoring and reporting.  The methods will also strengthen the 
economic underpinnings of country programs and strategies for the DMCs covered. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The key activities to be supported by the TA will include: preparation of background 
analytical papers; further development and refinement of analytical methods; drafting of ADO 
content; economic and copy editing; and preparation and layout of materials for publication. In 
addition, the TA will finance the procurement of information and knowledge services that may be 
required to support high-quality and up-to-date content and will support workshops, seminars, 
and training activities that are directly relevant to the preparation and strengthening of ADO and 
its dissemination. 
 
7.  The  terms  of  reference  of  background  analytical  papers  will  be  prepared  by  the 
Macroeconomics  and  Finance  Research  Division  (ERMF)  in  consultation  with  operations 
departments, as relevant. The objective of the papers will be to provide solid empirical and 
analytical foundation for ADO content.    
 
8.  Economic  and  copy  editing  activities  will  be  provided  by  international  consultants 
working  under  the  direction  of  the  assistant  chief  economist,  ERMF.  High-quality  editing 
services are crucial to ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency in approach across the 
different chapters and parts of ADO. 
 
9.  Training activities will focus on macroeconomic analysis, growth accounting, economic 
projections, and effective writing skills. Training will target economists in regional departments, 
national officers in resident missions, and, as appropriate, government officials and other client 
groups. The objective of the training is to equip writers with the skills and the tools needed to 
craft high-quality country chapters. Training will also impart skills that are of broader relevance 
for economic and sector work that underpins country strategies. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $380,000 (Appendix 3). The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  ADB will be the Executing Agency responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA.  
In particular, ERMF will implement the TA in close collaboration with regional departments (RDs, 
e.g., Central and West Asia, East Asia, South Asia, Southeast Asia, and Pacific) and resident 
missions (RMs). The assistant chief economist of ERMF, reporting to the chief economist of 
ERD, will be responsible for implementation. Given the high institutional profile of ADO, ERD will 
report to the Vice-President, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development Group and 
to the President at critical points in its preparation. 
 
12.  Developing analytical approaches and tools to support high-quality ADO content will be 
a collaborative effort involving ERMF economists, country economists of the RDs and RMs,   
national experts, international consultants, and economics editors. The TA will finance the 
procurement of information and knowledge services as may be required to support relevant and 
up-to-date content.  Procurement will be in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines

3
(April 2006, as amended from time to time). The TA is expected to start in December 2006 and 
to be completed by December 2007. 
 
13.  An ADO writers’ workshop for the country chapter writers and a workshop on Part 3 of 
ADO 2008 are tentatively scheduled for November 2007 at ADB headquarters.  The workshop 
on Part 3 will present the topic of the theme chapter for the subsequent year’s ADO, and will 
discuss issues and directions for the theme chapter.   
 
14.  For  ADO  2007  and  ADO  2007  Update,  it  is  estimated  that  10  person-months 
(approximately 5 consultants) of international consultants’ time will be required for economic 
and technical editing of ADO manuscripts before final publication. ADO will also require 5 
person-months  (approximately  2  consultants)  of  international  consultancy  resources  for 
preparing  background  papers.  Another  6  person-months  (approximately  2  consultants)  of 
national economic consultants’ time will be required to assist in preparing country chapters and 
data sheets.  Appendix 4 gives the outline terms of reference for the consultants and resource 
persons. The consultants will be hired as individuals. Resource persons will also be engaged to 
conduct training workshops and prepare background papers on economic trends and prospects 
of selected DMCs.  ADB will engage the consultants and resource persons in accordance with 
its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time). 
 
15.  ADB staff will disseminate the major results of ADO 2007 and ADO 2007 Update to the 
media,  DMC  policymakers,  and  civil  society.  The  TA  will  support  translation  of  ADO  into 
Chinese  and  Russian  languages  to  extend  its  audience  in  selected  DMCs.    This  will  be 
arranged by RDs in consultation with concerned RMs and DER. The dissemination activities will 
be coordinated by DER in cooperation with ERMF. In selected DMCs, the RMs will undertake 
separate launches and will be supported by ERMF. Both ADO 2007 and ADO 2007 Update will 
be featured on the ADB website and printed copies will be distributed worldwide. In countries 
where there is limited broadband access, CD-ROMs will be made available through the RMs. 
ERMF will work with DER to attempt to capture broader and more useful client feedback.   This 
activity may require some limited TA resources.   
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $380,000 on a grant basis for 
the Asian Development Outlook 2007, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Economics Consultants (5 person-months, 2 consultants) 
1.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general macroeconomics and 
good knowledge of the developing member country (DMC) economy. Under the direct supervision 
of the TA supervising unit (TASU) officer, the consultants will 
(i)  prepare thematic chapters and country reports as may be assigned; 
(ii)  work with the economics editor to ensure consistency and coherence of Asian 
Development Outlook (ADO);  
(iii)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by the assistant 
chief economist, Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division (ERMF). 
 
B.  International Economics Editor (6.5 person-months, 3 consultants) 
2.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF and in consultation 
with other Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff in the Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
involved in preparing and reviewing the country chapters in ADO 2007/ADO 2007 Update, the 
economics editor will edit the manuscripts for consistency and economic content. The editor will 
assist in preparing the highlights (English version) of the publication. The editor will also ensure that 
all the data in the publication is based on the most recent information available as of the specified 
cut-off date.  
 
3.  In particular, the economics editor will 
 
(i)  edit ADO for consistency with economic theory as well as empirical evidence; 
(ii)  edit ADO for internal consistency; 
(iii)  edit ADO for balanced coverage and degree of detail and precision; 
(iv)  check the report for structure, content, and format to ensure that it conforms to the 
prescribed requirements for ADO; 
(v)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in the  
  write-up; 
(vi)  confer with ERMF staff regarding gaps in the write-up, important questions, and 
needed revisions; 
(vii)  assist in preparing the publication highlights; 
(viii)  help prepare the key messages and review press releases for ADO; and 
(ix)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by the assistant 
chief economist, ERMF. 
 
C.  International Copy Editor-cum-Desktop Publishing Specialist (3.5 person-months, 2 
consultants) 
 
4.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF, and in consultation 
with the ADO production coordinator, the copy editor will (i) edit ADO 2007/ADO 2007 Update in 
accordance with ADB’s editorial style; (ii) be responsible for typesetting and proofreading the text, 
tables, and charts from the preliminary draft to the final copy and filming the output before forwarding 
to the external printer; (iii) be responsible for data linking to ensure data integrity and consistency in 
the final manuscript; and (iv) be responsible for converting the desktop file into pdf and html files for 
uploading on the ADB website. The copy editor must have full working knowledge of MS Office (MS 
Word and MS Excel), Adobe Pagemaker/InDesign, and Corel Draw/Illustrator.
